snippet: The Fat Duck chef shares recipes from the restaurant opening of the season.
lead_paragraph: Heston Blumenthal is one of the most forward-thinking chefs in the world. But his new restaurant, Dinner by Heston Blumenthal, is firmly rooted in the past — circa 1558. The London restaurant, which opens next month in the Mandarin Oriental overlooking Hyde Park, will champion British food from Tudor times up through that 20th-century invention, the ploughman’s lunch. ‘‘I was fascinated because I thought I knew quite a lot about cooking, and here I was, finding things I never knew existed,’’ he said of his extensive historical research. ‘‘There’s a sense of pride of introducing this stuff to people today.’’

snippet: Cheese twists, tarts and pinwheels are some of the recipe ideas Melissa Clark offers.
lead_paragraph: In my column on Wednesday, I wrote about the buttery joys of puff pastry, which is, along with butternut squash, Brussels sprouts, and newly picked Honeycrisp apples, one of my favorite autumn ingredients. I know what you’re thinking, and it’s true that technically puff pastry isn’t seasonal– you can buy it any time of the year. But if you’ve ever tried to roll out puff pastry in a humid New York summer, you’d understand my point. It’s best saved for sweater weather. So I like to do my bit for the seasonal cuisine movement by eating loads of puff pastry in the cooler months. Here are a few of my favorite ways to bake with puff pastry.
abstract: Cheese twists, tarts and pinwheels are some of the recipe ideas Melissa Clark offers.

snippet: Apple has sold more than three million iPads since April, but Amazon’s success with the Kindle is cloudier because it doesn’t reveal sales numbers.
lead_paragraph: THE Kindle from Amazon.com is designed to let us do one thing very well: read. To survive, it must excel at this, not only by jostling to stay a nose ahead of other e-readers, but also by maintaining an enormous lead over the Apple iPad and its coming competitors. The multipurpose iPad can do thousands of things very well; used for reading book-length texts, it doesn’t excel, but it’s passable.

snippet: Media Equation: The Apple iPad delivers a glimpse of the future, but are the people and companies who must provide media and applications for the device ready for its arrival?
lead_paragraph: In his Media Equation column Monday morning, David Carr takes a look at Apple’s ballyhooed iPad and concludes that its future will be determined by the coming flood of new applications and media deals. But even now, without them, it is clear that the new device is a glimpse over the horizon — “I couldn’t say the future had arrived, but I’m pretty sure you can see if from here,” Mr. Carr writes.

snippet: Like all corporate symbols, Google’s doodles are intended to tell us something about the company. So, what is it trying to say?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that you and a fellow Stanford computer science grad have just been given a $100,000 check to bankroll a new business. The Burning Man festival is coming up, and you both want to go. What do you do? If you’re Google’s Sergey Brin and Larry Page, you make a rough sketch of the wooden effigy that’s burned at the festival, add it to your Web site as an as an “Out of Office” sign and set off for the Nevada desert.

snippet: Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., downloaded the 10 billionth song from the company’s iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003.
lead_paragraph: And we have a winner! Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., clicked the “Buy Song” button at an opportune time, downloading the 10 billionth song from the company’s iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003. Mr. Sulcer will receive a $10,000 iTunes gift card for his fortuitous purchase of Johnny Cash’s “Guess Things Happen That Way.” Mr. Sulcer, a 71-year-old retired real estate broker, said in an interview that he learned about his achievement when Steve Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, called on Wednesday night. On Thursday he heard from Rosanne Cash, Johnny Cash’s daughter, who thanked him for buying one of her father’s tunes. She then put her husband, the musician John Leventhal, on the phone to play the winning song. Mr. Sulcer said he hadn’t had much time to think about how he would spend the winnings. “That’s the $10,000 question,” he said, though he said he expects that his three children and nine grandchildren would most likely benefit. “I don’t think I’ll have to worry about buying birthday and Christmas presents anytime soon.”
abstract: Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., downloaded the 10 billionth song from the company’s iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003.

headline.main: 10 Billionth Download for iTunes
headline.print_headline: 10 Billionth Download For iTunes

snippet: Not all flower arrangements need a vase — especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap fall’s bounty for a cool still life.
lead_paragraph: Not all flower arrangements need a vase — especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap fall’s bounty for a cool still life. It could be arranged on your mantel, or a maybe a sideboard, or even a centerpiece for your dining table (if there’s room). I can arrive at my friends’  house with a bag of produce from the market and a few items from my garden and do up an arrangement quickly and easily while sipping a drink. Here’s how you can, too.In the example here, I’m using white pumpkins — one big, several small — plus bittersweet vine, lady apples, small pears and a few  leaves. Persimmons and quince would have made this grouping that much better, for the fuzz and color they bring. Ultimately, it’s all about the mix, the color palette and a balance of big and small, linear and round.
abstract: Not all flower arrangements need a vase — especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap fall’s bounty for a cool still life.

headline.main: A Thanksgiving Arrangement

snippet: Music in the cloud, an Internet music service that everyone anticipates but which has not yet caught on, would cause problems for the music industry itself.
lead_paragraph: THE Apple iPad, which goes on sale April 3, will access video, applications and Web sites wirelessly — no cords or cables needed. But to move your trusty old music collection onto this wonder gadget and take it with you to work, or on vacation, you’ll have to pull out a U.S.B. sync cable, plug the device into your PC and transfer those music files over.

Bloggers also ask if the company will enforce its patent against other services, including Google Reader and Google Buzz, or if the move is just defensive.

snippet: The surprise hit “ — My Dad Says,”  which climbs to No. 1 this week, has inspired an imitation by a notoriously awful father.
lead_paragraph: STUFF LUKE’S DAD SAYS: “---- My Dad Says,” the potty-mouthed Twitter feed started last August by Justin Halpern, has earned its creator a television deal and, now, a No. 1 best seller. (The book moves to the top of the nonfiction list this week, supplanting “Spoken From the Heart,” a bunch of stuff Laura Bush said.) It has also inspired some imitators, including the Twitter feed “---- My Darth Says.” So far that one’s pretty unfunny, but let’s give Lord Vader his best shot: “If the Internet doesn’t settle down, I’m going to start a one-man campaign to feed Betty White to a Bantha.”
abstract: The surprise hit “ — My Dad Says,”  which climbs to No. 1 this week, has inspired an imitation by a notoriously awful father.

snippet: The New York-based jeweler Tito Pedrini interprets the pomegranate.
lead_paragraph: Whether Eve plucked an apple or a pomegranate from the tree may be up for debate, but there’s no doubt which fruit is sexier. Especially as interpreted by the New York-based jeweler Tito Pedrini, whose 18 karat gold “Pomegrani” earrings are as mouthwatering as the ancient superfruit itself. Comprised of pink opal, mammoth ivory or black onyx sprinkled with pink sapphire “seeds,” the earrings are $2,800. Call (212) 888-3355 for an appointment or go to titopedrini.com.
abstract: The New York-based jeweler Tito Pedrini interprets the pomegranate.

headline.main: Now Accessorizing | Forbidden Fruit

lead_paragraph: For a salad to make a meal, it should contain something more substantial, like grains, beans or potatoes, or protein-rich ingredients like cheese, fish or eggs. Poach an egg, place it atop a generous serving of frisée salad tossed with croutons, herbs and a tart vinaigrette, and you’ve got lunch or a light dinner. A spinach salad with green beans can be transformed into a comforting and nourishing meal when warm potatoes tossed with vinaigrette and feta are added to the mix. I’ve made this mixed-grains salad using both regular brown rice and brown basmati rice. I like the lightness of the basmati brown rice, but I also enjoy the chewiness of regular brown rice.

headline.main: Curried Rice and Quinoa Salad
headline.name: Curried Rice and Quinoa Salad

snippet: Need to speak to a business and don’t know the number? Just send a text and you’re connected.
lead_paragraph: Google’s GOOG411 service popularized a way for people to get business phone numbers for free, instead of paying up to $2.00 to get a phone number from a wireless or landline carrier. You just dial 800-GOOG411, and voice prompts ask for the name and city of the business, and the business name. When found, the voice recites the number, and either dials it for you or sends you the number and address as a text message.
abstract: Need to speak to a business and don’t know the number? Just send a text and you’re connected.

headline.main: No Talking Required for These 411 Calls

snippet: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apple’s foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pia...
lead_paragraph: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apple’s foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes gave an “elegant” performance of Beethoven in the “glass cathedral of commerce” on 67th Street, according to Anthony Tommasini. Tonight two famous first cousins once removed, Ira and Philip Glass will be at the company’s SoHo outpost beginning at 7 p.m. for the latest installment in the free performance series, iTunes Live. Wendy Sutter and the new ensemble, the Glass Chamber Players, will perform too.

snippet: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apple’s foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pia...
lead_paragraph: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apple’s foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes gave an “elegant” performance of Beethoven in the “glass cathedral of commerce” on 67th Street, according to Anthony Tommasini. Tonight two famous first cousins once removed, Ira and Philip Glass will be at the company’s SoHo outpost beginning at 7 p.m. for the latest installment in the free performance series, iTunes Live. Wendy Sutter and the new ensemble, the Glass Chamber Players, will perform too.

lead_paragraph:
For steamed crabs, that beach-town summer standby, the Chesapeake catechism teaches plenty: buy more crabs than you think you need, use more spice, a larger pot. Get wooden mallets. Prepare to eat for a while.

If you don’t have a crab pot, and most of us don’t, fiddle with the largest stockpot or pasta boiler you have. Set a few clean, empty metal cans upside down on the bottom or invert a colander in there, anything that allows you to have a boiling liquid at the bottom and crabs above it, with none of them swimming around in the soup.

snippet: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year.
lead_paragraph: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker owned by KKR & Company and Bain Capital, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year. NXP did not disclose the number of shares it intends to sell or at what price range in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The chipmaker, which is based in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, and has reported losses for three straight years, plans to use the proceeds to repay debt. NXP, with 27,000 employees, makes computer chips for a broad range of electronic device makers such as Nokia Oyj and Apple, according to the filing.

snippet: If a song on iTunes sells for 99 cents, how about a literary essay?
lead_paragraph: If a song on iTunes sells for 99 cents, how about a literary essay? On Tuesday, Scribner began publishing 69 essays by Chuck Klosterman, the pop culture and sports writer, available individually from retailers like Amazon, Apple and BN.com for 99 cents each. Nearly all the essays, which include “Fargo Rock City, for Real” and “All I Know Is What I Read in the Papers,” have appeared in print books before. But Scribner is hoping that people who have become accustomed to buying songs individually might do the same for stand-alone literary works. It will also publish digital collections of Mr. Klosterman’s essays  “Chuck Klosterman on Rock” and “Chuck Klosterman on Sports,” for instance  for $7.99 each.
abstract: If a song on iTunes sells for 99 cents, how about a literary essay?

headline.main: A Pay Model for Essays Taken From Itunes

snippet: Rugelach is just one of the mix-ins in Chozen, a new kosher ice cream.
lead_paragraph: Move over Soy Vay sauces. Chozen is a new kosher ice cream with mix-ins that would make Tevye happy. Rugelach, coconut-almond macaroon and chocolate matzo are the flavors, all swirled in a fine vanilla ice cream base with no gums or stabilizers. It started as a kitchen table concoction by Ronne Fisher and her daughters, Meredith Fisher and Isabelle Krishana, as they shared memories of traditional Jewish baked goods and ate homemade rugelach straight from the freezer. Nonetheless, one bite of the coconut-almond macaroon had me happily recalling a Good Humor toasted almond ice cream pop. Chocolate babka and honey-apple are future flavors. How about hamantaschen for Purim?
abstract: Rugelach is just one of the mix-ins in Chozen, a new kosher ice cream.

headline.main: In Kosher Ice Cream, a Taste of Traditional Baking

snippet: A few interesting ways to spend the weekend in New York City without spending a lot.
lead_paragraph: Any art lover can visit a museum, but the more adventurous can take to the streets for the New York City Department of Transportation’s free bike tour on Saturday. From 9:30 a.m. to noon, a guide will lead cyclists across Manhattan to murals, sculptures and mosaics sponsored by the Urban Art Program, an effort to invigorate the city’s streetscapes. At select stops, the artists will be on hand to talk about their work. Riders are invited to meet on the north side of 23rd Street and Broadway, at Madison Square Park, with bike, helmet, lots of water and a camera. (Registration is requested: rsvp.bikes@dot.nyc.gov or 212-839-7211.)
abstract: A few interesting ways to spend the weekend in New York City without spending a lot.

headline.main: A Bike Tour for Art Lovers, a Show for ‘Fela!’ Fans, Capoeira Lessons and a Korean Film

snippet: Bits: Amazon has pulled Macmillan titles from its site in a disagreement over e-book pricing.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has pulled books published by Macmillan from its site in a disagreement between the online retailer and the publisher over the price of e-books. For the moment, Macmillan books are available on Amazon only when bought through third parties. Macmillan, like other publishers, has been wrangling with Amazon over the retailer’s insistence that all e-books for its Kindle device be priced at $9.99. Many publishers want to charge more, or at least have more control over prices for individual books. The dispute hit a new level this week when Apple introduced its new iPad device, which will have an iBooks application through which publishers will have more control over e-book prices. The full story is here.
abstract: Bits: Amazon has pulled Macmillan titles from its site in a disagreement over e-book pricing.

headline.main: Bits: Amazon Pulls Macmillan Books from Its Site

snippet: A few interesting ways to spend the weekend in New York City without spending a lot.
lead_paragraph: Any art lover can visit a museum, but the more adventurous can take to the streets for the New York City Department of Transportation’s free bike tour on Saturday. From 9:30 a.m. to noon, a guide will lead cyclists across Manhattan to murals, sculptures and mosaics sponsored by the Urban Art Program, an effort to invigorate the city’s streetscapes. At select stops, the artists will be on hand to talk about their work. Riders are invited to meet on the north side of 23rd Street and Broadway, at Madison Square Park, with bike, helmet, lots of water and a camera. (Registration is requested: rsvp.bikes@dot.nyc.gov or 212-839-7211.)
abstract: A few interesting ways to spend the weekend in New York City without spending a lot.

headline.main: A Bike Tour for Art Lovers, a Show for ‘Fela!’ Fans, Capoeira Lessons and a Korean Film

snippet: Nokia has teamed with a working group that included Audi, BMW, Daimler, Porsche and Volkswagen to come up with a standard for interfacing smartphones with automobiles.
lead_paragraph: The more automakers work on integrating smartphones and their apps into the dashboard, the more confusing it gets. Just about every automaker is taking a different approach, creating headaches for drivers. One problem is that there is no industry standard, so Nokia and a group of five German automakers are proposing a new way of doing things.

snippet: The Mets will cut in half the height of the wall in straightaway center, a move meant mostly to increase the visibility of the Home Run Apple.
lead_paragraph: The Mets have seemingly made more changes to Citi Field this off-season than to their roster. All were cosmetic – think more blue and orange in and around the ballpark – but none were about to affect the course of a game. At least until Tuesday, when it was revealed that the Mets will chop in half the 16-foot wall that shields a sliver of straightaway center field – otherwise known as the area that houses the Home Run Apple. When the Mets begin the 2010 season April 5 against Florida, that fence, 408 feet from home plate, will stand 8 feet high. The modification was first reported by The Daily News.
abstract: The Mets will cut in half the height of the wall in straightaway center, a move meant mostly to increase the visibility of the Home Run Apple.

snippet: The stars at this handsome little storefront are the bomboloni — Italian filled yeast doughnuts that give the place its name.
lead_paragraph: Having weathered a nightmare of construction delays that cost him nearly a year, David Ruggerio will finally open his latest entry on Columbus Avenue, on March 17. The stars at this handsome little storefront are the bomboloni  Italian filled yeast doughnuts that give the place its name. They are usually about the size of golf balls or a little larger, but in Mr. Ruggerio’s hands they are more substantial puffy pillows about two and a half inches in diameter. The shop offers a dozen fillings, many injected to order, including chestnut, raspberry, Sicilian pistachio, apple and peanut butter, in addition to plain custard. Panini, soup, hot and cold coffee drinks (including flavored lattes) and gelati in fewer flavors than the bomboloni round out the menu.
abstract: The stars at this handsome little storefront are the bomboloni — Italian filled yeast doughnuts that give the place its name.

snippet: While I’m not about to sally north, “Into the Wild”-style, my respect of, and attraction to, the woods is ever-present.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the crisper air, my old sweaters and shinrin-yoku, I’m spending as much time as I can outside. While I’m not about to sally north, “Into the Wild”-style, my respect of, and attraction to, the woods is ever-present. One of my earliest memories is this 1979 National Film Board of Canada short, “The Log Driver’s Waltz,” from a song written by Wade Hemsworth, arranged and sung by Kate and Anna McGarrigle, with the Mountain City Four. Nature makes us better, and a log driver’s waltz pleases girls completely.
abstract: While I’m not about to sally north, “Into the Wild”-style, my respect of, and attraction to, the woods is ever-present.

snippet: A lightly sweetened fruit purée called Fruizo is now available at Simply Peeled on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Frozen confections come every which way this summer. The latest is a soft-serve, lightly sweetened fruit purée called Fruizo. Four partners, devoted to fitness and healthful food for their children, founded the business after experimenting for more than a year at home and then hiring consultants. The result, in a debut of mango, strawberry and banana flavors, all made from freshly puréed fruit rather than commercial purées, comes swirled into cups, by itself or accompanied by diced fruit, nuts, granola or other toppings. There are also smoothies and sundaes sold in this store, the partners’ first, which has a weathered country look even though much of the fruit comes from farms far away. Apple Fruizo will be added in the fall.
abstract: A lightly sweetened fruit purée called Fruizo is now available at Simply Peeled on the Upper East Side.

headline.main: A New Fruit Soft-Serve
headline.print_headline: Fruit Reinvented for Summer

snippet: Sade’s “Soldier of Love” is No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for the third week in a row. “Soldier of Love” sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000.
lead_paragraph: Sade’s “Soldier of Love” (Epic) is No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for the third week in a row. “Soldier of Love” sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cash’s “American VI: Ain’t No Grave” (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cash’s prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. (In another sign of how large Cash looms in pop music, his 1958 song “Guess Things Happen That Way” last week became the 10 billionth song downloaded from Apple’s iTunes store.)

snippet: The American Museum of Natural History Explorer application, available free from the iTunes store, connects to the institution’s wireless network to put information at visitors’ fingertips.
lead_paragraph: Among the crucial questions that occur on visits to the American Museum of Natural History: How did man get from a knuckle-dragging primate to a majestic bipedal creature? How did the mighty Tyrannosaurus rex use its tiny forelimbs to subdue its prey? And how do you get to the nearest bathroom? If you have an Apple mobile device, a new application can help you with all of those queries. In a news release the museum said its American Museum of Natural History Explorer application available free from the iTunes store, is compatible with the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch and connects to the institution’s wireless network to put information at visitors’ fingertips. In addition to providing a GPS and turn-by-turn walking directions to any of the exhibitions, theaters, shops, restaurants and bathrooms in the building, the application also provides additional details on more than 140 displays (including the blue whale, of course), customizable tours, a fossil treasure hunt for children and connections to Facebook and Twitter. (Above, visitors at the museum.)
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History Explorer application, available free from the iTunes store, connects to the institution’s wireless network to put information at visitors’ fingertips.

headline.main: Museum Offers a New Iphone App
headline.print_headline: Museum Offers a New iPhone App

snippet: T’s fall Design & Living issue offers plenty of good reasons to cheer for the home (design) team.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees may not have made it all the way this year, but T’s winter Design & Living issue offers plenty of good reasons to cheer for the home team. Our cover story singles out half a dozen young designers who are making it big in the Big Apple. Elsewhere in the issue, Pilar Viladas tours the architect Tom Kundig’s latest house and discovers it to be as comfortable on the inside as it is rugged on the outside; Sandra Ballentine drops in on the public art maven Yvonne Force Villareal and gets an eyeful of her colorful private life; and William Middleton visits a little modern house on a big freeway. We meet the knit wit Donna Wilson, whose kooky creature comforts are on display this month at the Future Perfect stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and shadow the design world’s stealth supplier, the American born, Zurich-based dealer Arthur Rooks. Jonathan Adler rekindles an old flame — the Malm floating fireplace — and Fred A. Bernstein writes about the horrors of being a houseguest. No place like home indeed!
abstract: T’s fall Design & Living issue offers plenty of good reasons to cheer for the home (design) team.

headline.main: Now Online | T Design & Living Winter 2010

snippet: Beautiful but dangerous, jimsonweed sent British soldiers who used it in a salad into a stupor for 11 days. We find it in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Jimsonweed has been on my radar ever since I researched it for a presentation on wild weeds and fungi last year, so I was intrigued when I discovered some spiny seedpods recently in an alley in Gowanus, Brooklyn. Originally thinking they were empress tree pods, which are similarly sculptural but smooth, I brought them back to my workspace, where a friend helped to correctly identify them as Datura stramonium, or jimsonweed, and their source (the garden of a local artist around the corner).
abstract: Beautiful but dangerous, jimsonweed sent British soldiers who used it in a salad into a stupor for 11 days. We find it in Brooklyn.

headline.main: Urban Forager | In This Wicked Weed, the Devil’s Trumpet Blows

snippet: Forget its utility. Apple’s new tablet computer is pure beauty and pleasure.
lead_paragraph: At its christening in April, the Apple iPad was declared an instrument for consumers of media — a sort of cultural spoon. This struck many as bad news. Though the Web would seem to have blurred the line between content producers and content consumers, old antagonisms die hard. Producers are still imagined as lean, fierce and manly, where consumers are seen as feminized, passive and fat. Alex Payne, a tech entrepreneur, found the iPad disturbing: “a digital consumption machine.” On the great tech site Boing Boing, Cory Doctorow — while resolving never, ever to buy an iPad — took the trouble to remind us that a consumer is (in the novelist William Gibson’s acid words) “something the size of a baby hippo, the color of a week-old boiled potato, that lives by itself, in the dark, in a double-wide on the outskirts of Topeka.”
abstract: Forget its utility. Apple’s new tablet computer is pure beauty and pleasure.

headline.main: The Aesthetics of the iPad
headline.print_headline: Sweetness And Backlight

snippet: The Internet was once an unruly place. Are apps gentrifying it?
lead_paragraph: The Web is a teeming commercial city. It’s haphazardly planned. Its public spaces are mobbed, and signs of urban decay abound in broken links and abandoned projects. Malware and spam have turned living conditions in many quarters unsafe and unsanitary. Bullies and hucksters roam the streets. An entrenched population of rowdy, polyglot rabble seems to dominate major sites.
abstract: The Internet was once an unruly place. Are apps gentrifying it?

headline.main: The Death of the Open Web
headline.print_headline: The Death of the Open Web

snippet: The Upper West Side cafe also sells a bake-at-home kit for its signature treat.
lead_paragraph: Carol Baer has been serving big, crusty popovers, the signature of her Upper West Side restaurant, Popover Café, since 1981. From time to time, she has made miniature ones for catered events, mainly for hors d’oeuvres and desserts, but also for dinners. “They’re more delicate and less filling,” she said. Now, the mini-popovers are on the cafe menu; diners can choose four of them instead of one big one, or a basket of a dozen in place of three. Her Web site now sells a kit for baking the minis at home, including mix, a pastry brush, raspberry jam or apple butter and two pans, each making 12. There is enough mix to make many more than the 24 popovers the two pans can hold.
abstract: The Upper West Side cafe also sells a bake-at-home kit for its signature treat.

headline.main: The Popover Café Offers Mini Version
headline.print_headline: When There’s Too Much of a Good Thing

snippet: Epix has struck a development deal for a new series called “iCon,” to be written by Dan Lyons, who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs.
lead_paragraph: If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday, the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called “iCon,” to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, and in his novel “Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs – A Parody.” The project, which Epix described in a news release as “a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley CEO whose ego is a study in power and greed,” is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of “Borat,” “Religulous” and “Brüno” and a veteran writer and producer of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm”; the half-hour, single camera series will be produced by Media Rights Capital.
abstract: Epix has struck a development deal for a new series called “iCon,” to be written by Dan Lyons, who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs.

snippet: Melissa and Emily Elsen, who have opened the cafe Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Gowanus, Brooklyn, come from a pie-making family in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Pie-making is in the DNA of Melissa (at center in photo) and Emily Elsen (at left). Their grandmother baked pies for their mother’s restaurant in Hecla, S.D., and it was from her that they learned their craft. And now, after a year of baking pies for a growing list of clients, they have opened a bakery and cafe in Gowanus, Brooklyn. There’s an open kitchen in the rear of the whitewashed store, rustic tables and chairs in front of the counter, and restored decorative touches, like patterned pressed tin.
abstract: Melissa and Emily Elsen, who have opened the cafe Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Gowanus, Brooklyn, come from a pie-making family in South Dakota.

lead_paragraph: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. But can it help you to imagine that you’re Captain America, brandishing your shield and fists against the ruthless Red Skull? Yes, it can do that, too. On Friday, Marvel Comics, the publishing home of heroes like Spider-Man and the X-Men, said it was introducing a free application for the iPad that will give readers access to a digital library of more than 500 comics from its 70-year history. The software program, Marvel Comics App, developed by the digital comics distributor comiXology, offers free access to the first issues of titles like New Avengers and The Invincible Iron Man. Other recent and vintage issues can be downloaded for $1.99 each. Marvel says it sees the app as being complementary to the experience of buying and reading physical comics, not supplanting it. “That Wednesday, when people go to the stores, I call it a mini Comic-Con,” Ira Rubenstein, the executive vice president of Marvel’s global digital media group, said in a telephone interview. “It’s where fans gather and talk about the books and they argue about the books and speculate about the books. That experience isn’t going to change.”
abstract: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. That experience isn’t going to change.”

headline.main: Can the Ipad Do What a Comics Store Can?
headline.print_headline: Can The iPad Do What a Comics Store Can?

snippet: Melissa and Emily Elsen, who have opened the cafe Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Gowanus, Brooklyn, come from a pie-making family in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Pie-making is in the DNA of Melissa (at center in photo) and Emily Elsen (at left). Their grandmother baked pies for their mother’s restaurant in Hecla, S.D., and it was from her that they learned their craft. And now, after a year of baking pies for a growing list of clients, they have opened a bakery and cafe in Gowanus, Brooklyn. There’s an open kitchen in the rear of the whitewashed store, rustic tables and chairs in front of the counter, and restored decorative touches, like patterned pressed tin.
abstract: Melissa and Emily Elsen, who have opened the cafe Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Gowanus, Brooklyn, come from a pie-making family in South Dakota.

headline.main: Sisters Open a Pie Shop in Brooklyn
headline.print_headline: Plenty of Tradition But No Blackbirds In These Sisters’ Pies

lead_paragraph: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. But can it help you to imagine that you’re Captain America, brandishing your shield and fists against the ruthless Red Skull? Yes, it can do that, too. On Friday, Marvel Comics, the publishing home of heroes like Spider-Man and the X-Men, said it was introducing a free application for the iPad that will give readers access to a digital library of more than 500 comics from its 70-year history. The software program, Marvel Comics App, developed by the digital comics distributor comiXology, offers free access to the first issues of titles like New Avengers and The Invincible Iron Man. Other recent and vintage issues can be downloaded for $1.99 each. Marvel says it sees the app as being complementary to the experience of buying and reading physical comics, not supplanting it. “That Wednesday, when people go to the stores, I call it a mini Comic-Con,” Ira Rubenstein, the executive vice president of Marvel’s global digital media group, said in a telephone interview. “It’s where fans gather and talk about the books and they argue about the books and speculate about the books. That experience isn’t going to change.”
abstract: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. The software program, Marvel Comics App, developed by the digital comics distributor comiXology, offers free access to the first issues of titles like New Avengers and The Invincible Iron Man. Other recent and vintage issues can be downloaded for $1.99 each. Marvel says it sees the app as being complementary to the experience of buying and reading physical comics, not supplanting it. “That Wednesday, when people go to the stores, I call it a mini Comic-Con,” Ira Rubenstein, the executive vice president of Marvel’s global digital media group, said in a telephone interview. “It’s where fans gather and talk about the books and they argue about the books and speculate about the books. That experience isn’t going to change.”

snippet: Only 20 of the 106 items in the Mostly Mozart Festival this year are by Mozart.
lead_paragraph: The 19 Percent Mozart Festival doesn’t exactly roll off the tongue. But by at least one crude calculation, that is what Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival has become. The festival is announcing its season on Monday, and of the entries in the chronological listing (truly apples and oranges, ranging in size from a brief canon by Bach to Handel’s extended pastoral ode “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” some of them given multiple performances), only 20 of the 106 items are by Mozart, above. No fewer than 34 composers will be represented in this year’s outing, which runs July 27 to Aug. 21. Many of those are contemporary figures, represented in a six-concert series, “Bach and Polyphonies,” organized by the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, who is artist in residence. Louis Langrée, the festival’s music director, and the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra will open and close the season with (mostly) Mozart. There will also be Mozart orchestral evenings conducted by Lionel Bringuier and Osmo Vanska, and smaller-scale programs devoted to Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin. The Handel ode, a festival favorite in the 1988 production by the choreographer Mark Morris, will return for three performances at the David H. Koch Theater (Aug. 5-7). There will also be nine of the festival’s late-night concerts in the Kaplan Penthouse.
abstract: Only 20 of the 106 items in the Mostly Mozart Festival this year are by Mozart.

headline.main: At Mostly Mozart, a Lot of Others Too
headline.print_headline: At Mostly Mozart, a Lot of Others Too

snippet: At One Twenty Three, a contemporary redo of offerings, with sheer sauces and many salads, joins a list of greatest hits.
lead_paragraph: SOME might remember the Toska brothers, Rui and Aris, who in 1988 transformed the Hearth restaurant into L’Europe, introducing a menu of fancy French-Continental dishes — still in their butter-and-cream heyday — to Vista, then a sleepy area of South Salem. Many years and several renovations later, Jeff Toska (Aris’s son) took over the restaurant, renamed it One Twenty Three (the number of the route it’s on), and gave the menu a decidedly contemporary cast, with most sauces thin or sheer and salads galore.

snippet: A selection of news of interest in the San Francisco Bay area.
lead_paragraph: 10,000 Turn Out for Pleasanton Tea Party Rally | Political candidates like Carly Fiorina, the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer, went to the Alameda County Fair Grounds to rally Tea Party followers to their campaigns. But most of the talk during the five-hour rally focused on general discontent with the Obama administration’s economic policies and the recently passed health care legislation. “This is great timing for us,” said Bridget Melson, the president of the Pleasanton T.E.A. (Taxed Enough Already) Party and the event’s organizer. “The passing of the health care bill has incensed and fired people up.” Among the slogans visible at the event was: “Vote the traitors out in November.” A New York Times poll shows that Tea Party supporters are wealthier than the general public, tend to be Republican and classify themselves as “angry.” [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]
abstract: A selection of news of interest in the San Francisco Bay area.

snippet: The British painter David Hockney takes his landscapes and portraits to a popular medium: the iPad.
lead_paragraph: The British painter David Hockney has never confined himself to just one artistic medium. (Remember the Polaroid collages?) True to form, he was quick to embrace the iPhone’s Brushes app, among others. Even as he was working on large-scale landscapes of his native Yorkshire, England — for a big 2012 exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London — Hockney was drawing energetic, vividly colored images of flowers, places and people at screen scale, which he e-mails to friends. These, along with his drawings on the iPad, are the subject of ‘‘David Hockney: Fleurs Fraîches,’’ which runs from Oct. 20 to Jan. 30, 2011, at the Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent Foundation in Paris. Curated by Charlie Scheips and designed by the New York architect Ali Tayar of Parallel Design, the exhibition will present the artwork in its original digital format, including animations of one or more works. (Brushes records the process of a painting in video.) The iPhones and iPads themselves will be set into fiberboard panels like the ones that line Hockney’s studio, and Tayar is even designing special furniture for the installation — which Scheips says ‘‘won’t look like an Apple store. It will be more homey.’’ The act of iPainting seems no less immediate for its lack of actual pigments; Scheips says Hockney becomes so immersed that he stops to wipe off his fingers.
abstract: The British painter David Hockney takes his landscapes and portraits to a popular medium: the iPad.

headline.main: Finger Painting

snippet: Only 20 of the 106 items in the Mostly Mozart Festival this year are by Mozart.
lead_paragraph: The 19 Percent Mozart Festival doesn’t exactly roll off the tongue. But by at least one crude calculation, that is what Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival has become. The festival is announcing its season on Monday, and of the entries in the chronological listing (truly apples and oranges, ranging in size from a brief canon by Bach to Handel’s extended pastoral ode “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” some of them given multiple performances), only 20 of the 106 items are by Mozart, above. No fewer than 34 composers will be represented in this year’s outing, which runs July 27 to Aug. 21. Many of those are contemporary figures, represented in a six-concert series, “Bach and Polyphonies,” organized by the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, who is artist in residence. Louis Langrée, the festival’s music director, and the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra will open and close the season with (mostly) Mozart. There will also be Mozart orchestral evenings conducted by Lionel Bringuier and Osmo Vanska, and smaller-scale programs devoted to Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin. The Handel ode, a festival favorite in the 1988 production by the choreographer Mark Morris, will return for three performances at the David H. Koch Theater (Aug. 5-7). There will also be nine of the festival’s late-night concerts in the Kaplan Penthouse.
abstract: Only 20 of the 106 items in the Mostly Mozart Festival this year are by Mozart.

headline.main: At Mostly Mozart, a Lot of Others Too
headline.print_headline: At Mostly Mozart, a Lot of Others Too

snippet: The Schoolhouse Theater mounts Molière’s classic French comedy “The Imaginary Invalid.”
lead_paragraph: It might be nice to report that the Schoolhouse Theater has mounted Molière’s classic French comedy “The Imaginary Invalid” in order to add its two cents to the nation’s health care discussion. But for better or worse, and I suspect it’s for better, Pamela Moller Kareman’s production seems to have been intended just for the fun of it. To the extent that there’s commentary, it’s all Molière’s, as the much-abused intimates of Monsieur Argan  and in particular, his marriageable daughter  cope with his all-consuming hypochondria.
abstract: The Schoolhouse Theater mounts Molière’s classic French comedy “The Imaginary Invalid.”

snippet: What made the meeting of Mitchell and Cam’s lips so remarkable was how incidental it was to the story.
lead_paragraph: To the extent that it is possible for a genial and widely lauded comedy like “Modern Family” to get itself into trouble (at least in a way that doesn’t involve hyping the Apple iPad), that ABC series caused a minor stir in the spring: after an episode in which Claire and Phil Dunphy, a married couple played by Julie Bowen and Ty Burrell, were shown kissing, while Mitchell Pritchett and Cam Tucker, a gay couple played by Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Eric Stonestreet, were hugging, some fans of “Modern Family” complained that the show would not allow its gay characters to kiss, going so far as to start a Facebook campaign demanding such a scene. The “Modern Family” producers countered that an episode involving a kiss between Cam and Mitchell was already in the works.
abstract: What made the meeting of Mitchell and Cam’s lips so remarkable was how incidental it was to the story.

snippet: A look at news of interest in the San Francisco Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: A Bid to Tax Medical Marijuana | To help close its $14 million budget shortfall this year, the Berkeley city manager has unveiled a plan to tax three medical marijuana dispensaries at a rate of $10 per square foot of the space they occupy. The dispensaries pay the city $20,000 a year in business license fees based on sales. “Taxing sick people’s medicine is not the best way to make up their financial shortfall,” said Erik Miller, manager of the Patients Care Collective, who opposes the tax. Last year, Oakland voters approved a sales tax on the city’s medical marijuana dispensaries and now collects $18 for every $1,000 in sales. [The Oakland Tribune]

snippet: Unlike their counterparts in the United States, traditional English scones are barely sweet, and they’re lighter, flakier and tastier.
lead_paragraph: MOST scones in this country are overly sweet and loaded up with some ridiculous combination of raisins, apples, cherries, chocolate chips, almonds, ginger and perhaps a few other ingredients. Traditional English scones are actually barely sweet, though they’re usually eaten with sweet jam and clotted cream, which is not easy to find here. In general they’re lighter, flakier and tastier than what you buy. And they’re easy to make.

snippet: Introducing Greetje, an Amsterdam restaurant that lives up to Holland’s rich culinary history.
lead_paragraph: There are dozens of reasons to love Amsterdam, but the food isn’t one of them. To be sure, the city has several terrific Indonesian restaurants, like Sampurna and Blue Pepper, legacies of Holland’s colonial past. (Indonesia was a Dutch colony for more than three centuries.) And there’s De Kas, which serves excellent produce-driven menus in a beautifully restored 1926 greenhouse. I also love running amok at De Kaaskamer, the ideal spot for a tour of Dutch cheeses. But unlike most other major European cities, Amsterdam is a gastronomically deracinated destination. The streets are lined with gauche gaucho steakhouses, middling pasta palaces, wok wielders, burger joints and shawarma stands galore, and, more recently, a torrent of Mad Med tapas taverns.
abstract: Introducing Greetje, an Amsterdam restaurant that lives up to Holland’s rich culinary history.

headline.main: Eurofile | Dutch Treat

snippet: A roundup of news of interest to residents of the San Francisco Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: Judge Weighs Gang Injunction | The latest effort by regional law enforcement authorities to use the court system to control gang violence will be under the microscope in Alameda County Superior Court, where officials will press for an injunction to control Oakland’s North Side gang. It would restrain 15 named individuals from a variety of activities, including weapons possession, trespassing and witness intimidation. It would also keep suspected gang members from associating with one another in a 100-block swath of the city and impose a curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. In other Bay Area cities, like Fairfield, civil liberties groups have attacked such injunctions as violations of constitutional rights. In Oakland, opponents argue that an injunction would do little to curb crime and much to prompt racial profiling. A report in The Bay Citizen said that a series of at least four killings put law enforcement’s focus on the north Oakland group. [The Oakland Tribune, The New York Times, The Bay Citizen]Proposition Billed as Antidote to Polarization | Proposition 14, backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is gaining traction. The initiative would replace traditional primaries in state and Congressional elections with twofold elections. All candidates would run in the first round. The top two vote-getters, regardless of party affiliation, or lack thereof, would face each other in the general election. Voters’ ultimate choice could be two Republicans or two Democrats, but it is likely that they would be the best-known or the wealthiest of the original field. Supporters say the measure would empower moderates and increase turnout. The state’s $19 billion deficit, high unemployment and low morale may help the measure’s chances; polls show a majority of voters favor it. [The New York Times]
abstract: A roundup of news of interest to residents of the San Francisco Bay Area.

headline.main: Sampler: Oakland Gang Injunction Mulled, and Point Reyes Light Sold

snippet: In his first solo exhibition, Tim Hawkinson tinkers with scale and moving parts while grappling with issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time.
lead_paragraph: Tim Hawkinson likes to tinker. In his first solo exhibition with the Los Angeles gallery Blum & Poe, which opened on Saturday, the artist not only tinkers with scale, moving parts and myriad materials, but also grapples with big life issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time. The centerpiece of the exhibition is a monumental kinetic sculpture called “Orrery,” a reference to apparatuses that represent the motions and phases of the solar system. A larger-than-life figure of a woman, at once benign and sinister — is she Mother Time, perhaps? — sits at a spinning wheel made of recycled plastic bottles. Everything about the sculpture is circular, interconnected and eternally spinning  — the woman’s ears, fingers and the bun on her head;  the spinning wheel and the circular platform on which she sits. Even the pattern on her dress, a motion illusion designed by a Japanese psychology professor, seems to spin. The effect is hypnotic as both viewer and figure cycle between the material and cosmic worlds.
abstract: In his first solo exhibition, Tim Hawkinson tinkers with scale and moving parts while grappling with issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time.

headline.main: Life and Other Cycles | Tim Hawkinson at Blum & Poe

snippet: Should I glow or shimmer? Aspire to radiant luminosity or incandescent iridescence? Apparently, I can have it all.
lead_paragraph: The Samurai Shopper, though possessed of boundless wisdom, is afflicted with a waggish skepticism — chalk it up to experience. I had to abandon the passionate energies and utter stupidity of youth. There wasn’t a choice; birthdays happened. I do miss my younger self, especially the part where I awoke each morning looking radiantly fresh, like a shiny penny in a mud puddle. Now it takes many, many shiny pennies to find illumination, which mainly comes from skin-care counters. Like the Doge’s Palace in Venice, my exterior has borne the insults of time and seeks restoration to the alabaster glory that once was me. Besides, bright people don’t deserve dull skin.
abstract: Should I glow or shimmer? Aspire to radiant luminosity or incandescent iridescence? Apparently, I can have it all.

headline.main: Samurai Shopper | Age of Enlightenment

lead_paragraph: With the playoffs underway, few N.B.A. players would dream of covering their eyes. Their ears? That’s another story — especially where music is concerned. But flash headphones are an absolute must.

snippet: This week’s Tech Talk includes an Electronic Frontier Foundation lawyer’s views on privacy on Facebook and what not to do on social networks.

Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kurt Opsahl, a senior staff attorney at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an online civil liberties group. He says it’s getting harder, and more complicated, to use Facebook’s privacy settings, and he objects to the site making personal data public by default.

snippet: How the White House should react to Scott Brown’s win.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scenario, believe it or not, in which Scott Brown’s stunning win last night could actually end up forestalling a massive G.O.P. sweep next November. It involves Barack Obama swallowing his pride, behaving like a President who’s just been thumped, and making a very public show of internalizing the lessons of last night in Massachusetts. And it involves dismissing, immediately and with prejudice, the liberal fantasy that Rahm Emanuel should spend the next few weeks “knocking heads together” in the House, in the hopes of pushing the Senate bill through Congress.
abstract: How the White House should react to Scott Brown’s win.

headline.main: Time For The Re-Set Button

snippet: What is it that makes young women think that, in order to prove they’re no longer girls, they must oversexualize themselves to the point of absurdity?
lead_paragraph: Some of us here at ArtsBeat — those of the female persuasion as well as the male — went to bed last night unable to get our minds off Erica Rhodes’s “American Idol” audition. We hoped that by the time we woke up, the day’s agenda would be dominated by new business: the State of the Union address; the Apple iPad; the John Edwards tell-all book. But here we are, a whole half-rotation of the earth later, and we’re still troubled by that audition. Why?
abstract: What is it that makes young women think that, in order to prove they’re no longer girls, they must oversexualize themselves to the point of absurdity?

lead_paragraph: AT first glance, it seems that Bespoke, formerly owned by the New Haven restaurant mavens Arturo and Suzette Franco-Comacho, has changed little. The new proprietors, Lauren Kendzierski and her father, John Kendzierski, have wisely retained the Franco-Comachos’ elegant décor, including that incredible onyx fireplace that still dominates the mezzanine. Even the steel-gray menu jackets are the same, though they have begun to look worn around the edges.

snippet: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast: Brian Stelter on the Google-Verizon net neutrality plan and Miguel Helft on the BlackBerry brouhaha.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast,  Brian Stelter, a Times media reporter, drops by to chat about Internet access regulation with J.D. Biersdorfer and Bettina Edelstein. The so-called net neutrality plan of Google and Verizon would exempt wireless and some other online services from rules for maintaining open access to the Internet, and Mr. Stelter says that while the two companies  appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating broadband.

snippet: How the White House should react to Scott Brown’s win.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scenario, believe it or not, in which Scott Brown’s stunning win last night could actually end up forestalling a massive G.O.P. sweep next November. It involves Barack Obama swallowing his pride, behaving like a President who’s just been thumped, and making a very public show of internalizing the lessons of last night in Massachusetts. And it involves dismissing, immediately and with prejudice, the liberal fantasy that Rahm Emanuel should spend the next few weeks “knocking heads together” in the House, in the hopes of pushing the Senate bill through Congress.
abstract: How the White House should react to Scott Brown’s win.

headline.main: Time For The Re-Set Button

snippet: A gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europe’s other great sea.
lead_paragraph: Though any reference to Estonian cooking generally draws a blank stare from even well-traveled gourmets, Alexander, one of the best and most interesting new restaurants in Europe right now, is found on the tiny and stunningly beautiful Estonian island of Muhu, a two-hour drive south from Tallinn, the country’s capital. It’s still rather confidential, but a gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europe’s other great sea, the Baltic, which has long been dismissed as a region of marginal culinary interest by a world besotted with everything Mediterranean.
abstract: A gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europe’s other great sea.

lead_paragraph: “The Soprano State: New Jersey’s Culture of Corruption” strikes a lighthearted, if cynical, tone as it reviews some of the worst recent scandals. The documentary presents itself as a nightclub act, with Tony Darrow, who played small parts in “The Sopranos” and “Goodfellas,” narrating from a stage while lounge-lizard music is piped in. But the message of the film, based on the 2008 book of the same name by the longtime Trenton reporters Bob Ingle and Sandy McClure, is relentlessly bleak.

snippet: This week’s podcast includes a way to use cellphones to test eyesight, a push to educate consumers about safety online and “ransomware.”
lead_paragraph: On this week’s New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Ramesh Raskar, an M.I.T. Media Lab associate professor, about a system he and his students developed that uses a cellphone screen, a small plastic device and software to test vision and calculate eyeglass prescriptions. According to Dr. Raskar, the results are as reliable as a more conventional method of testing eyesight. The system, called the Near-Eye Tool for Refractive Assessment, is inexpensive to produce and use, and because cellphones are so widespread it has the potential to help millions of people around the world with impaired vision, Dr. Raskar says.

headline.print_headline: Rachel Alexandra Loss Imperils Showdown

snippet: Which camera should you use when size matters more than image quality?
lead_paragraph: The best camera, as they say, is the one you have with you. With this in mind — and a very capable Sony DSC-R1 collecting dust in my office because its honking Carl Zeiss lens makes it too bulky to bring anywhere fun — I decided to invest in a new point-and-shoot. I had read great things about the Panasonic Lumix GF1, so requested one to test. The verdict: Truly. Amazing. Camera. Unfortunately, the thing requires some seriously deep pockets, thanks to both a $1,000 sticker price and a sizable (though impressive) detachable Leica lens.
abstract: Which camera should you use when size matters more than image quality?

headline.main: Street Shooters | Style Bloggers’ Camera Picks

snippet: With a little shredding, grating, chopping, slicing or mincing, the robust flavors of late fall vegetables are allowed take center stage.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH I’m not suggesting you bite into a raw hunk of butternut squash or gnaw on a head of cabbage (though the latter can actually be pleasant), there’s great pleasure to be found in feasting on autumn vegetables served raw, with a minimum of preparation. With a little shredding, grating, chopping, slicing or mincing, the tough, sometimes starchy character of late fall vegetables yields, allowing their robust flavors to take center stage.
abstract: With a little shredding, grating, chopping, slicing or mincing, the robust flavors of late fall vegetables are allowed take center stage.

headline.main: Vegetables for Thanksgiving, Served Natural and Raw
headline.print_headline: The Bounty of Fall, Served Natural and Raw

snippet: “Pyaar Impossible,” the latest romantic comedy from the Hindi-film powerhouse Yash Raj Films, is sweet, and as formula goes, deftly done and satisfying.
lead_paragraph: The latest romantic comedy from the Hindi-film powerhouse Yash Raj Films, “Pyaar Impossible” is, like most Yash Raj movies, a fairy tale. And like most of the company’s pictures, it is also well made (if formulaic), enriched by slick production values and set in glossy faraway places: It begins at something called Ankert University in a tropical-pastoral paradise called California, touches down briefly in Mumbai and then settles in Singapore.
abstract: “Pyaar Impossible,” the latest romantic comedy from the Hindi-film powerhouse Yash Raj Films, is sweet, and as formula goes, deftly done and satisfying.

headline.main: Love Story That Flits Across Time and Space
headline.print_headline: Love Story That Flits Across Time And Space

abstract: An exhibit at the Johalla Projects gallery is showing 50 artists’ unconventional views of Chicago’s 50 aldermen.

snippet: Research is teasing apart the phonetic components of babble, along with the interplay of neurologic, cognitive and social factors.
lead_paragraph: As a pediatrician, I always ask about babble. “Is the baby making sounds?” I ask the parent of a 4-month-old, a 6-month-old, a 9-month-old. The answer is rarely no. But if it is, it’s important to try to find out what’s going on.
abstract: Research is teasing apart the phonetic components of babble, along with the interplay of neurologic, cognitive and social factors.

snippet: At A Toute Heure, the menu changes every week and relies on local produce.
lead_paragraph: DAYS, even weeks after visits to A Toute Heure, I’m still smiling. I’m enamored of its small, sweet dining room, its earnest staff and its carefully sourced food. A Toute Heure — which translates to “anytime” — is a good restaurant that spikes to very good, with optimism on the plate and in the dining room.

headline.main: A Menu That Changes as the Garden Grows

snippet: This week’s podcast includes a way to use cellphones to test eyesight, a push to educate consumers about safety online and “ransomware.”
lead_paragraph: On this week’s New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Ramesh Raskar, an M.I.T. Media Lab associate professor, about a system he and his students developed that uses a cellphone screen, a small plastic device and software to test vision and calculate eyeglass prescriptions. According to Dr. Raskar, the results are as reliable as a more conventional method of testing eyesight. The system, called the Near-Eye Tool for Refractive Assessment, is inexpensive to produce and use, and because cellphones are so widespread it has the potential to help millions of people around the world with impaired vision, Dr. Raskar says.
abstract: This week’s podcast includes a way to use cellphones to test eyesight, a push to educate consumers about safety online and “ransomware.”

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Testing Eyesight and “Ransomware”

snippet: A new form of storytelling and a discussion about dating in a digital world are among the topics this week.
lead_paragraph: New technologies have always brought new ways of telling stories. On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer talks to Anthony Zuiker, the creator of the hit TV show “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” about his latest digi-novel, “Dark Prophecy.” What’s a digi-novel? As Mr. Zuiker explains, it’s “the best of publishing, motion picture and social communities all kind of meshed into one experience.” Every 25 pages, readers get a code they can take to a Web site, where they can watch a video segment that bridges the chapters. “Dark Prophecy,” a thriller, is the second book in Mr. Zuiker’s “Level 26″ series. He tells Ms. Biersdorfer that an iPad app with interactive features is expected next month.
abstract: A new form of storytelling and a discussion about dating in a digital world are among the topics this week.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Digi-Novels and Dating

snippet: Shelving analog calendars for digital ones.
lead_paragraph: I miss my Filofax datebook, with its six rings and dark red leather binder. I had a green one first, with a calendar that cast each week across two cream-colored pages. Back then, at age 30, I was not busy enough to need a whole page per day, which some Filofax calendars provide, but far too busy, or so I liked to imagine, to fit a week’s activities on a single page. I left that green one in a taxi and replaced it with a red one. Old reddie is still around, with my life during half of 2007 memorialized. Even when I started half-heartedly to use iCal, Apple’s personal-calendar program for the Mac, I lugged around the Filofax in case I needed — I don’t know — the address book? The dry-measure equivalent for “bushel”? The dialing code for Saudi Arabia? The size conversions for tailors (“Glove sizes are the same in every country”)? The centigrade temperature in Accra in May?
abstract: Shelving analog calendars for digital ones.

headline.main: The Demise of Datebooks
headline.print_headline: THE MEDIUM; Calendar Daze

snippet: The area south of San Francisco buzzes with cultural spaces, lively restaurants and a hyper-educated workforce that has no problem keeping up.
lead_paragraph: LIKE the high-tech companies that give this lush region its name, Silicon Valley thrives on reinvention. Situated just south of San Francisco Bay, the valley was once an agricultural cradle, home to orchards and vineyards. These days, of course, it bears fruit of a different sort, as the home of tech giants like Apple, Google and Intel. Buoyed by the resilience of tech companies, the valley’s dozen or so cities, which include Mountain View and Palo Alto, have managed to sidestep the recession, continuing their shift from corporate strip malls to urban hubs. The valley now buzzes with cultural spaces, lively restaurants and a hyper-educated workforce that has no problem keeping up.
abstract: The area south of San Francisco buzzes with cultural spaces, lively restaurants and a hyper-educated workforce that has no problem keeping up.

snippet: Student Opinion | Do you think an increase in teachers tampering with students’ standardized tests and scores shows that changes in education are putting too much pressure on your teachers?
lead_paragraph: An article today reports on an increase in teachers caught tampering with their students’ standardized tests and scores. Because those scores now often determine which teachers get bonuses and tenure, some say the higher the stakes are, the more teachers will cheat. Do you agree? Do you think this shows that changes in education, including the testing required under No Child Left Behind, are putting too much pressure on your teachers? Or do you think there are just a few “bad apples” who cheat, and that public school teachers are no more pressured than they ever were? Do you think it’s fair to judge teacher performance on student scores in general?
abstract: Student Opinion | Do you think an increase in teachers tampering with students’ standardized tests and scores shows that changes in education are putting too much pressure on your teachers?

snippet: This week’s topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint.
lead_paragraph: Although the Federal Trade Commission last week dropped its investigation of personal data inadvertently collected by Google’s StreetView cars, state authorities and officials in European and other countries are still looking into privacy issues related to the service. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a New York Times technology reporter who covers Google, about the latest developments. Ms. Miller says that Google has taken new steps aimed at protecting privacy, which satisfied the F.T.C., but consumer groups and privacy advocates are dismayed about the agency’s decision. Google recently revealed that in addition to location photos, its StreetView cars gathered passwords and e-mail from unencrypted Wi-Fi networks.
abstract: This week’s topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Online Privacy

snippet: Barb Jungr, the British chanteuse, sings of water with emotional dynamite, at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: Nobody but Barb Jungr, the brilliant British chanteuse who inserts sticks of emotional dynamite into songs of every vintage, would dream of connecting “Lazy Afternoon,” the Jerome Moross-John Latouche standard from “The Golden Apple” with the 1968 Small Faces hit, “Itchycoo Park.” And on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, Ms. Jungr found a powerful link. Prefacing the songs with a monologue about youth and age and how when you’re young you have time to burn, she showed how both are really about lying around and getting high.

snippet: This week’s topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint.
lead_paragraph: Although the Federal Trade Commission last week dropped its investigation of personal data inadvertently collected by Google’s StreetView cars, state authorities and officials in European and other countries are still looking into privacy issues related to the service. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a New York Times technology reporter who covers Google, about the latest developments. Ms. Miller says that Google has taken new steps aimed at protecting privacy, which satisfied the F.T.C., but consumer groups and privacy advocates are dismayed about the agency’s decision. Google recently revealed that in addition to location photos, its StreetView cars gathered passwords and e-mail from unencrypted Wi-Fi networks.
abstract: This week’s topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Online Privacy

snippet: The salty risers are being incorporated into both sweet and savory culinary compositions.
lead_paragraph: Around here, it seems like every day is National Pretzel Day. New Yorkers used to have two basic choices: a pigeon-worthy pedestrian softy from a Sabrett-umbrellaed cart or City Bakery’s haute pretzel croissant. Some housemade strays turned up here and there — one in the breadbasket at Commerce, another at Kurt Gutenbrunner’s Blaue Gans and, naturally, the expected Biergarten regulation. A few months ago, though, there was an explosion of artisanal twists and braids. Now, the salty risers tempt at every turn and are being incorporated into both sweet and savory culinary compositions.
abstract: The salty risers are being incorporated into both sweet and savory culinary compositions.

headline.main: Hyphen Trouble

snippet: After decades of magical dietary thinking, a father finally gets the wisdom of whole grains.
lead_paragraph: Lately, every chance I get, I have been working whole grains into the meals we serve our sons, Dexter and Elliot. The cabinets and the freezer are stockpiled with farro, oatmeal, wild rice, polenta and bags of not-white flour: whole wheat, spelt and buckwheat. The change in our diet is most noticeable on Saturday and Sunday mornings, when Dexter and I usually make pancakes or waffles. Just six months ago, we were following a white-flour-dominated recipe that either one of my grandmothers would have recognized. Our most recent batch of pancakes incorporated whole-grain rye flour and cornmeal along with half a cup of cooked quinoa. If my goal was to transport my sons back to the kitchen of some Nixon-era communally owned radical-feminist vegetarian tea parlor without anybody figuring out that we had left 2010 Brooklyn, then the pancakes were a wild success.
abstract: After decades of magical dietary thinking, a father finally gets the wisdom of whole grains.

headline.main: Pretzel Logic
headline.print_headline: Pretzel logic

snippet: After decades of magical dietary thinking, a father finally gets the wisdom of whole grains.
lead_paragraph: Lately, every chance I get, I have been working whole grains into the meals we serve our sons, Dexter and Elliot. The cabinets and the freezer are stockpiled with farro, oatmeal, wild rice, polenta and bags of not-white flour: whole wheat, spelt and buckwheat. The change in our diet is most noticeable on Saturday and Sunday mornings, when Dexter and I usually make pancakes or waffles. Just six months ago, we were following a white-flour-dominated recipe that either one of my grandmothers would have recognized. Our most recent batch of pancakes incorporated whole-grain rye flour and cornmeal along with half a cup of cooked quinoa. If my goal was to transport my sons back to the kitchen of some Nixon-era communally owned radical-feminist vegetarian tea parlor without anybody figuring out that we had left 2010 Brooklyn, then the pancakes were a wild success.
abstract: After decades of magical dietary thinking, a father finally gets the wisdom of whole grains.

headline.main: Pretzel Logic

snippet: Forget Deauville. Etretat is Normandy’s best kept secret. Population: 1,000.
lead_paragraph: Just two hours northwest of Paris and an hour or so south of the better-known — and far more crowded — Norman towns of Deauville and Trouville, Etretat feels like a secret weekend escape. Accessed from Paris by an almost absurdly bucolic train ride to Breauté Le Havre (followed by a short bus ride into Etretat; directions are here), the seaside town has just 1,000 inhabitants, many of them erstwhile Parisians who retire there for its spectacular vistas, lovely gardens, mild weather and such local delicacies as goat cheese, Calvados, apple jam and salted caramel.

lead_paragraph: General Electric’s shareholders seem curiously overjoyed to see the conglomerate back in shopping mode. The company added $4.2 billion to G.E.’s market cap on Wednesday, when it spent $3 billion on an energy infrastructure business, confirmed its interest in a British maker of oil pipes and snapped up some of Citigroup’s more questionable loans. It is a shift from years on the defensive, selling assets. But the celebration looks overdone.

snippet: Shareholders welcomed G.E.’s purchases on Wednesday, including a $3 billion deal for an energy infrastructure business, but the conglomerate has overspent in the past.
lead_paragraph: General Electric’s shareholders seem curiously overjoyed to see the conglomerate back in shopping mode. The company added $4.2 billion to G.E.’s market cap on Wednesday, when it spent $3 billion on an energy infrastructure business, confirmed its interest in a British maker of oil pipes and snapped up some of Citigroup’s more questionable loans. It is a shift from years on the defensive, selling assets. But the celebration looks overdone.
abstract: Shareholders welcomed G.E.’s purchases on Wednesday, including a $3 billion deal for an energy infrastructure business, but the conglomerate has overspent in the past.

Critics derided John McCain’s font, Optima, which was developed in the 1950s, and recalled the printing on a remedy for gastric distress.

snippet: Pumpkin is at home in many holiday dishes — cornbread, savory pies, puddings, even gelato. Plus: favorite dishes for Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: I never got around to carving a jack-o’-lantern for Halloween. I bought the pumpkin, yes, but then decided to save it for cooking. The day after Halloween, I cut it into chunks — about eight pounds — put them on foil-lined baking sheets, covered the sheets and roasted them at 425 degrees until they were very soft, which took about 1 1/2 hours. Then I spent the week making pumpkin recipes.

snippet: If there is a heaven, some sort of afterlife, I like to think of it as a place where we get reunited with all the good dogs that we’ve ever known.
lead_paragraph: As I get older, and especially since I learned two years ago that I had an aggressive prostate cancer, I linger even longer and more lovingly over the past. But I’m not just tugged at by the satisfactions of mere nostalgia. In following those lonely and haunted dirt roads back to my childhood, I’m on a quest to try to understand the adult I’ve become.
abstract: If there is a heaven, some sort of afterlife, I like to think of it as a place where we get reunited with all the good dogs that we’ve ever known.

headline.main: All the Good Dogs You’ve Loved Before

They let the sensors collect data for about 36 hours and then rounded them back up.
abstract: Can journalism and computer science mix?

snippet: The new trend: parents are being asked to bridge the gap between what students need and what taxpayers will pay for.
lead_paragraph: Our school district’s budget passed this week, as did 92 percent of those in New York State, but it is a shell of its former self. While my tax rate will increase about 3 percent under the new budget, the district will actually decrease its spending by 1.1 percent, leading to the dismissal of seven teachers and 34 aides and assistants. The cuts come in the wake of the $1.4 billion the state plans to cut from the education budget, leading districts to cut their own.
abstract: The new trend: parents are being asked to bridge the gap between what students need and what taxpayers will pay for.

lead_paragraph: Six years ago, I decided to write a cookbook that would gather the best New York Times recipes ever. I was sure it was a great idea, because the paper — which began publishing recipes in the 1850s— has been one of the leading voices in the evolution of American food. But it turned out to be a terrible idea logistically, because The Times has published tens of thousands of recipes. So I turned to the paper’s readers — you! — a group of people I barely knew, for help, placing a small author’s query in the Dining section, soliciting readers’ “most stained recipes” from The Times.

snippet: Nine months after Justin Halpern started a Twitter feed that we’ll call “Stuff My Dad Says,” he has a book on the nonfiction list and a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner.
lead_paragraph: FATHER KNOWS BEST: Last August, Justin Halpern was a 28-year-old semi-employed comedy writer living with his parents in Los Angeles when he decided to start posting his 73-year-old father’s irascible, foul-mouthed wisdom on a Twitter feed that we’ll call “Stuff My Dad Says.” Nine months later, he has more than a million followers, a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner (tentatively titled “Bleep My Dad Says”) and a book at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list. It’s tough to quote from the book in a family newspaper, but a few recent nuggets from the Twitter feed give a bit of the flavor. On being a proud papa: “A parent’s only as good as their dumbest kid. If one wins a Nobel Prize but the other gets robbed by a hooker, you failed.” On marriage: “Pressure? Get married when you want. Your wedding’s just one more day in my life I can’t wear sweat pants.”
abstract: Nine months after Justin Halpern started a Twitter feed that we’ll call “Stuff My Dad Says,” he has a book on the nonfiction list and a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner.

headline.main: Inside the List
headline.print_headline: Inside the List

Ready to pick?” That was the greeting from Billie Jo Tunis, who for 16 years has worked the cherry season— as well as apricot, peach, pear and apple seasons — at LoveApple Farm, in Ghent, N.Y. When a customer said she might be ready to pick cherries once she had had a cup of coffee, Ms. Tunis pointed to a tray of dimpled pastries. “We have warm cherry turnovers, right from the oven,” she said. “Now, who could resist one of those with a cup of coffee?”

snippet: In the dystopia of this wry first novel, a hierarchical society forces young bachelors to find brides — or else.
