snippet: Who’s got the city’s best buns?
lead_paragraph: Lately, buns — sometimes holy — have been on everyone’s minds, bodies and menus. As a nod to Good Friday, with apologies to anyone who’s off leavened items this week, here’s a guide to the Big Apple’s best buns: sticky, cinnamon, hot cross and otherwise:STICKY BUNSLet’s start at the very beginning with a small bakery on Madison Avenue at 83rd Street, William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. When I was a child, my father went here for schnecken. The German word for snail, its reference is the spiral shape of the thing. In fact, while I identify schnecken with this particular rich-doughed, cinnamon-filled, raisin-laden, pecan-topped, caramelized breakfast staple, the label is as generic as “danish,” and can be used to describe any flattened, coiled, cinnamon-raisin pastry. Sadly, William Jr. sold his bakery a number of years ago and the goods don’t taste the same. If you want to experience a sticky bun as I knew it, you can go two blocks down to E.A.T., where Eli Zabar has created something that rivals the Greenberg classic. Or else call Scarsdale, where William’s son Seth continues to bake (and sell) his father’s schnecken. Seth uses the same ingredients as his dad and has the original 1930s recipe cards to prove it. You can taste the sour cream and butter in the dough; the perfectly burnt brown sugar in the thick glaze.
abstract: Who’s got the city’s best buns?

headline.main: The Bun Report | Hot, Cross and Sticky

lead_paragraph: The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has found a way to give its fallen trees a new life: as hand-turned bowls and vases made by Ivan Braun, a woodworker from the Bronx. The one-of-a-kind objects, sold at the garden, are crafted in yew, red maple, plum, juniper, white oak, cherry, apple and zelkova, a Japanese elm. (Mr. Braun used the zelkova to create dramatically striated bowls with a pinto-pony effect, right.) They range from $45 to $145.

The one-of-a-kind objects, sold at the garden, are crafted in yew, red maple, plum, juniper, white oak, cherry, apple and zelkova, a Japanese elm. (Mr. Braun used the zelkova to create dramatically striated bowls with a pinto-pony effect, right.) They range from $45 to $145.
abstract: The woodcarver uses scraps from the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx to make his hand-turned bowls and vases.

headline.main: Ivan Braun, Who Turns Felled Trees Into Bowls
headline.print_headline: If a Tree Falls, Does It Aspire to Become a Bowl?

snippet: The president of Planned Parenthood is sometimes a homebody, sometimes a puzzle junkie.
lead_paragraph: Cecile Richards, 52, a onetime labor organizer and co-founder of America Votes, an umbrella organization of liberal groups concentrating on voter turnout,  has been president since 2006 of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Ms. Richards, the daughter of the late Ann Richards, who was governor of Texas, lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Kirk Adams, 60, a health care organizer for the Service Employees International Union. Their three children no longer live at home; the couple recently downsized to an apartment near Central Park. ROBIN FINN
abstract: The president of Planned Parenthood is sometimes a homebody, sometimes a puzzle junkie.

snippet: “Arcimboldo, 1526-1593: Nature and Fantasy” shows the artist as more than just an inspiration for the Surrealists.
lead_paragraph: Of all the Mannerists’ winks, smirks and capers, the composite heads imagined by the 16th-century Milanese painter Giuseppe Arcimboldo must be the weirdest. Substituting fruits, vegetables and other bits of the natural world for human features, they tease the eye and sometimes turn the stomach. A ripe pear, for instance, looks suddenly unappetizing once it’s made to serve as a chin.
abstract: “Arcimboldo, 1526-1593: Nature and Fantasy” shows the artist as more than just an inspiration for the Surrealists.

headline.main: Several Obsessions, United on the Canvas

snippet: Freelance Cafe and Wine Bar is the 21-year-old creation of Peter X. Kelly, who also has X2O Xaviars, Xaviars and Restaurant X.
lead_paragraph: PETER X. KELLY is a culinary star. He beat Bobby Flay on “Iron Chef America” in 2007. He was nominated for a 2010 James Beard Foundation award for best chef in the Northeast. And his restaurants in New York’s lower Hudson Valley  X2O Xaviars on the Hudson in Yonkers, Xaviars at Piermont and Restaurant X and Bully Boy Bar in Congers  are among the most ambitious and popular in the region.

snippet: Brands like Converse are becoming the new record labels.
lead_paragraph: RIGHT now it is just a shell, the peeling remnant of an old dry cleaner on a graffiti-covered block in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. But soon the 5,200-square-foot space will be transformed into a sleek new recording studio in the heart of the underground-rock capital. And in the latest twist in pop’s relationship with Madison Avenue, the struggling bands making music there will already be encountering corporate America: the studio is being built by Converse, which will let them record free.
abstract: Brands like Converse are becoming the new record labels.

headline.main: Looking to a Sneaker for a Band’s Big Break
headline.print_headline: Looking to a Sneaker For a Band’s Big Break

snippet: A musical that’s often a diva vehicle allows other actors to shine.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Alexander doesn’t bat her eyes or belt her lyrics with abandon as Dolly Gallagher Levi in the Gateway Playhouse production of “Hello, Dolly!” at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts. She doesn’t invite applause for making an entrance, even when she appears at the top of that red staircase in the title number. She stays in character, a widow trying to make a living as a matchmaker and self-described “meddler.”
abstract: A musical that’s often a diva vehicle allows other actors to shine.

headline.main: Dolly! (Modestly)

snippet: Designers who literally break the mold.
lead_paragraph: As a design critic, I consider it my job to decide whether things are well designed and, if so, why. Because they’re environmentally sound? Ethical? Innovative? Emotionally expressive? All good reasons, sure, but sometimes we’re drawn to things simply because they give us a warm, fuzzy feeling, which is harder to explain. And I felt it recently when I spotted a set of strangely shaped water carafes at a design show in Milan.
abstract: Designers who literally break the mold.

headline.main: Object Lesson | The Imperfectionists

snippet: The summer is young, and the backyard grill is ready for something new. Expand your cooking repertory with these ideas.
lead_paragraph: THERE, in all of their Fourth of July glory, are 101 grilling ideas begging to be tried. A vast majority take less time to prepare and grill than it takes to watch your coals turn white. (If you use gas, they’re still almost as fast as heating up the grill.) Some of them feature ingredients like corn, eggplant and tomatoes, which will be better a month from now, at least in the Northeast. But there are also suggestions for foods in season right now that not everybody thinks of putting on the grill. Please note that salt and pepper are (usually) understood.
abstract: The summer is young, and the backyard grill is ready for something new. Expand your cooking repertory with these ideas.

headline.main: 101 Fast Recipes for Grilling

snippet: Mary Wittenberg, who will direct the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7, limits her own endurance running to half-marathons.
lead_paragraph: Her days of running marathons are over: her knees made that decision for her. But Mary Wittenberg, who entered and won her first race after a happy hour dare while attending college in Buffalo, still plans her life around the sport. As president of the New York Road Runners Club, which she has led since 2005, she is directing the New York City Marathon, to be held Nov. 7. Ms. Wittenberg, 48, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Derek, a banker, and their two sons, Alex, 9, and Cary, 8. ROBIN FINN
abstract: Mary Wittenberg, who will direct the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7, limits her own endurance running to half-marathons.

headline.main: No Rest for a Long-Distance Runner

snippet: Tasca, a three-night pop-up food event at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, nudged people, pleasure, and domestic life closer together.
lead_paragraph: Marco Velardi, Omar Sosa and Nacho Alegre, the trio of twenty-somethings behind the Milan- and Barcelona-based indie design magazine Apartamento have a flair for celebrating the reality of everyday life. And for just plain celebrating. The magazine is an invitingly DIY affair, and so was Tasca, Apartamento’s three-night pop-up food event at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which, true to form, seemed to take its cue from an inescapable reality of all design fairs: that while it’s stimulating to take in the latest Kartell creation or to shake hands with a Bouroullec, the most pressing issue on everyone’s overloaded mind — particularly after a forced march through an arena-sized exhibition hall — isn’t rapid prototyping or just how post postmodernism is. It’s dinner: Where it’s going to happen, when and with whom.
abstract: Tasca, a three-night pop-up food event at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, nudged people, pleasure, and domestic life closer together.

headline.main: Home Cooking | Your Apartamento or Mine?
